title: Agriculture and Fishery Regulatory Support Program
description: The Department of Agriculture plays a principal role in ensuring safe and quality agricultural and fisheries products for consumers as well as facilitating trade of the same. This role calls for a farm-to-fork approach to ensuring quality and safety now being demanded by the local and foreign markets and consumers for the products they buy and consume. It also plays a critical role in protecting our borders from the entry of risks to human, plant, and animal health and life. It is imperative therefore that the regulatory offices of the DA must strengthen their delivery of services by recognizing and implementing reforms and practices aligned with the best international principles and practices.
expected_outputs:
1. Provide a strong and reliable pest and disease control method by the use of quarantine stations and checkpoints for the early detection and emergency response to local and exotic animal and plant diseases that may cause negative impact on production, international trade and public health.
2. Provide an efficient web-based public service in the application and approval of permits
3. Ease of Business permit processing which is favorable for more business undertakings to thrive 
4. Provide standard guidelines for Registration, Licensing and Accreditation of agribusiness enterprises and other related businesses, including import/export sanitary and phytosanitary permits/clearances 
5. Monitor and maintain records of Incidences. Cases and Outbreaks of major plant pests and animal diseases and design appropriate prevention and control measures
6.Systematic and scientific prevention, control and eradication of economically significant plant pests and animal diseases. 
7. Quality and safety assurance of food of plant and animal origin 
8. Conduct periodic/regular inspection of food/feed products available in the market for quality and safety assurance 
9. Conduct periodic/regular inspection and monitoring of food/feed/veterinary drugs and products manufacturing establishments and facilities along with their counterpart animal feeds/diagnostic laboratories 
10. Develop Standards/Codes for Good Practices in Agriculture (GAP), Animal Husbandry (GAHP) and Aquatic Resources (GAqP)
pdp_indicators: Economic opportunities in agriculture, forestry and fisheries expanded
pdp_ss_outcomes: Agriculture, forestry and fisheries productivity within ecological limit improved

title: AMAS - Improvement of the Value Chain of Selected Vegetables in Selected Areas in the Philippines
description:
The project aims to increase market efficiency and reduce post-harvest losses in the vegetable industry through the improvement of marketing practices and the introduction of new technologies/systems. We would like to improve the processes along the value chain to get better prices for farmers' produce.In the long-run, we would like our farmers to be able to effectively engage in entrepreneurship in order to be able to sell directly to consumers/buyers thereby reducing the multi-layered marketing system for vegetables.	

Specifically, this aims to improve the farming practices, post-harvest and marketing system with new and appropriate technologies to provide better value of farmers' products; to capacitate AMAS, AMAD, LGUs, and farmers with new farming, value-adding, and marketing technologies.

title: ATI - Rice Competitiveness Enhancement Fund - Rice Extension Services Program (RCEF-RESP)
description:
The general objective of the RCEF-Extension Program is to conduct strategic extension services the capability of Rice Fund beneficiaries in modern rice and seed production and other relevant skills for improved competitiveness and income. 

Specifically, the Program shall aim to:

1. Improve knowledge, attitudes, and skills of Rice Fund beneficiaries in producing more rice at reduced production cost through training programs, enterprise development assistance, and communication support services; 

2. Increase access to modern, science-based farming techniques and other relevant skills by developing farm schools and strengthening their capacities on rice knowledge/technology transfer; and

3. Enable availment of training programs under the Rice Fund through a scholarship scheme.

1) Food Security –The program of increasing food production by utilizing native animals;

title: BFAR - Global Sustainable Supply Chains for Marine Commodities
description:
This project contributes to address key aspects of the market forces that drive overfishing. The project will add to the transformation of the seafood market by mainstreaming sustainability in the value chain of important commodities platforms, and fisheries improvement projects (FIP), developing national capacities, and generating learning to be shared worldwide. The project will allocate GEF resources strategically to 1) engage major seafood buyers in the main world markets (EU, Japan, US) into responsible sourcing, providing tools to prepare and implement sustainable seafood sourcing policies, 2) adapt the concept of green commodities platforms in Costa Rica, Ecuador, Indonesia and Philippines to generate experience that could be used in other countries, 3) support stakeholders of these platforms to develop practical experience with fisheries improvement projects and upgrade existing tools for FIP implementation and monitoring, and 4) upgrade existing information platforms to facilitate access to reliable materials to value chain stakeholders in support of sound decision making, and capturing documenting and disseminating the learnings of the project. The project target fisheries include tuna fisheries in the Pacific Ocean, Mahi-mahi and large pelagic fish in the Eastern Pacific Ocean, Indonesian snapper, Octopus and blue swimming crab fisheries in Philippines.
The project is an inter-regional intervention. Market engagement and knowledge management are global components. The sustainable marine commodities platforms and FIPs will be implemented, using a participatory approach in Costa Rica, Ecuador, Indonesia and Philippines.
expected_outputs: Increased capacities of key duty bearers to provide enabling environment for claim holders Improved access to an enhanced natural resource base, sustainable energy and cleaner environment.
pdp_indicators: Economic opportunities in agriculture, forestry and fisheries expanded / Access to economic opportunities by small farmers and fisherfolk increased
pdp_ss_outcomes: Agriculture, forestry and fisheries productivity within ecological limit improved / Agriculture, forestry and fishery-based enterprises increased / Access to value chains increased

title: BFAR - Integrated Marine Environment Monitoring System - Phase 3 (IMEMS)
description:
The complete IMEMS system which comprises of Phases I, II & III will provide DA-BFAR with a powerful and fully integrated fisheries, marine environment & aquatic life management and monitoring system which covers the entire Philippine fishing industry. IMEMS III will extend the existing IMEMS system to include the monitoring of all commercial and municipal vessels operating in Philippine waters, and thus result in a single integrated system that manages and monitors all Philippine fishing vessels.

The project aims to significantly improve and extend the existing capabilities of the BFAR Vessel Monitoring System (VMS) and operationalize a Single Integrated National Marine Environment Monitoring System that is financially viable and scalable over the long term.
expected_outputs: Single Integrated National Marine Environment Monitoring System for both commercial and municipal vessels established and operationalized.

title: BFAR - Rehabilitation of Aquaculture Irrigation Systems and Mariculture Areas
description:
The project will undertake desilting activities in brackishwater fishponds irrigation systems (rivers, creeks, major and secondary canals)with severe siltation which cannot provide the required water volume due to shallowness caused by erosion, including the desilting activities of organic waste deposited at the sea bottom within the mariculture areas.

The main purpose of the proposed project is to clean the aquaculture irrigation systems (rivers, creeks, primary and secondary canals) and clear the fish sewage or organic waste deposited in sea bottom within mariculture areas through the procurement of cleaning equipment.
expected_outputs:
1. Purchased 17 units floating long reach excavator/back hoe. 
2. Purchased 3 units motorized barges 
3. Purchased 6 units suction pumps with 25 meters hose
4. Purchased units dump trucks
5. Excavated  1,275,500 cubic meter mud/silt deposit
6. Increased productivity of aquaculture production area from current level of 1.61 mT/ha/yr to 5.485 mT/ha/yr

description:
This project will serve as the Phase 2 of the Phase 1 implementation of BFAR's Vessel Monitoring System (VMS) and integration of various databases including fishing vessel registry, ocean and weather data, stock assessment data, IUUF records and other regulatory information.  The PHILO project is dedicated to set up an integrated operational fisheries and marine environment monitoring center in the Philippines.  Through this project, BFAR will be able to monitor fishing vessels and combat illegal fisheries in order to protect the maritime resource in a sustainable way, support the national fishing industry, and promote seafood products for export.

The project aims to significantly improve and extend the existing capabilities of the BFAR Vessel Monitoring System (VMS) and operationalize a Single Integrated National Marine Environment Monitoring System that is financially viable and scalable over the long term.

title: BPI - Enhancing Productivity and Producing High Quality Tomato Through Smart Greenhouse In The Philippines
description: This project is a small scale project that will be implemented by the  DA-BPI under a  Public-Private Partnership (PPP) Agricultural Project with Korean International Cooperation Agency (KOICA) and Korean private companies . The project aims to enhance production competitiveness of small and mid-sized farmers by establishing greenhouse technology for high value added agro-products, and increase farmers income by enhancing distribution channel in related to co-branding and local shipping in the Philippines.   The Korean Smart Farm Greenhouses offers the Philippine agriculture a possible solution to the country's climate change concern being experienced by our highland vegetable growers. It would be also a showcase for Good Agricultural Practice, addressing the food safety requirements in the Food Safety Law in the country.   The piloting of the Korean Style Greenhouse is also an avenue to get the advance climate proof greenhouse technology which can be utilized in organic crop production, and eventually gain an easy access to Korean market to boost Philippine agriculture. Aside from the productivity, the established operating software  will provide greenhouse environment information to farmers by mobile to help them manage operating risk. Also, the environmental and production data collected through the software will guide to establish environmental control system optimized in the local environment of the Philippines.
expected_outputs: Smart Greenhouse constructed and  operating system established

title: BPI - The Making into a SCICAT of the Seeds and Seedlings  (S&S) Plaza
description: In support to agri-tourism, BPI-LBNCRDPSC proposed and established the S&S Plaza which is strategically situated at the back of DOST-PCAARRD Technology Innovation Center (DPITC) building. The plaza generally aims to promote different technologies on planting material preparation as showcased in different edible landscape designs. This locally-funded project aims to transform the S&S Plaza into a SciCAT Farm Enterprise that will serve as one of Laguna’s main tourist farm attraction showcasing BPI and PCAARRD developed technologies.
expected_outputs: One (1) SciCAT Farm Accredited by the Department of Tourism (DOT)

title: BSWM - ACIAR Soil Project (Soil and Nutrient Management Strategies for Improving Tropical Vegetable Production in Southern Philippines and Australia)
description:
The project is conducted in collaboration with VSU as project leader (for Philippines), BSWM, UPLB among others.  The project aims to improve crop productivity of small holder farmers in Southern Philippines by developing technologies, programs and strategies for cost-effective productive production of vegetables while sustaining the natural resource base.  the project served as basis to inform the public, the policy maker on the merits of organic and conventional production and the capacity for widespread organic implementation to meet Philippines vegetable needs 

The project aims to identify the key soil and nutrient constraint; assess the productive capacity, fertility and sustainability of organic, conventional and protected vegetable production; and develop strategied to improve efficiency of fertilizers and overcome nutritional and soil acidity constraint to vegetable production

title: DA RFO IVB - Establishment of Cassava and Corn Starch Processing Facility
description: The facility will be used by Carabao Cassava Cluster, a group beneficiary in the province of Occidental Mindoro, for  processing of cassava and corn into food grade starch intended for institutional market (e.g., Nestle Food Corporation). expected_outputs: Carabao Cassava Cluster will processed the cassava and corn produced in the two producing Municipalities (Rizal and Abra De Ilog).  The produced by product  (starch)  will be marketed/delivered to Nestle Food Corporation in the locality.

The specific objective is to improve agriculture-based livelihoods of smallholder farmers, increase their productivity, improve food security and nutrition through the provision of agricultural inputs, appropriate training and technical assistance on improved agricultural and diversified farming system.

title: DA-FPOPD - Farmers and Fisherfolks Database, ID System and Farm Geo-Referencing
description:
This project aims to create a centralized and nationwide  farmers and fisherfolks database that would support various levels of planning, decision-making, and delivery of interventions for the Department of Agriculture.  The database contains information on farmers, farm laborers, and fishermen and their farm parcel. The database can significantly improve the delivery of programs and services of the Department of Agriculture while making the data available to other agencies that share the same stakeholders as the DA.

It includes conduct of nationwide validation and registration of farmers and updating of the existing farmers registry.

This project also includes printing and distribution of  farmer's intervention card that will serve as a single and standard identification system for all registered farmers. The farmer's ID card can be used as a first level validation and authentication of DA beneficiaries.

Along with the ID card, this project will also provide a Farmer's Passbook / booklet  that list down all the interventions that the farmers can avail from DA. The booklet will also act as the farmer's own record book of his farming activities.
expected_outputs: Farmers and fisherfolks database, National ID system for Farmers and Fisherfolks, Farmers and Fisherfolks Passbooks

pdp_ss_outcomes: Agriculture, forestry and fisheries productivity within ecological limit improved

title: Expansion of the Philippine Rural Development Project
description:
The proposed expansion of the PRDP with additional financing from the World Bank is critical to maintain the institutional momentum for implementing the reforms and new ways of doing business under PRDP.  It is also vital to sustain the unprecedented level of LGU support that has come through the devolved partnership arrangements under the PRDP.  

Given the fast turnout for infrastructure investments, the proposal to avail of USD 450 Million additional loan proceeds from the World Bank will mainly to cater to the excess demand and the prospective proposals for rural infrastructures.

Infrastructure Development â€“ this component aims to improve the links from production areas to markets to enhance the efficiency of transporting agricultural products. It also aims for higher productivity as a result of increased cropping intensity and yields, food security and improved health from readily available potable water and lower post harvest losses resulting in higher volume of outputs and more efficient support facilities.


Project Support â€“ this component aims to provide efficient and effective project management and implementation, establish a standard on services and technical assistance and effective mode of engagement with LGUs.
expected_outputs:
(a) 16 regions with subprojects under implementation
(b) 81 provinces with PCIPs prepared
(c) 3,600 km of roads and 2,000 linear meters of bridges  constructed/rehabilitated 
(d) 550 hectares of irrigation services areas generated from newly constructed rehabilitated CIS
(e) 45,000 households provided with access to rehabilitated/constructed PWS
(f) 300 units of various post production and marketing facilities constructed/rehabilitated
(g) 1,500 enterprise established along the priority value chain


(Above listed items are outputs of the original loan and expansion of PRDP)

title: Halal Food Industry Development Program
description:
The Department of Agriculture is one of the core National Government Agencies in Halal Industry Development Program as stipulated on the Republic Act 10817 "Philippine Halal Export Development and Promotion Act". the following sections are stated on the said law, below are the following:  
1. Section 10, Philippine National Standards for Halal - The DA- BAFS will play a vital role in primary and post-harvest foods standards; 2. Section 12, Export Promotion - The DA is one of the agencies that will support the DTI on the enhancement of the exports promotion;  3. Section 13, Infrastructure Support and Incentives - The DA also mandated to enhance the growth of Halal industries and assist farmers and producers in complying with the relevant standards on halal, the government DA also mandated to provide and/or upgrade necessary common facilities such as slaughterhouses, warehouses, refrigeration facilities and laboratories and equipment, in strategic production, processing and manufacting areas. 4. Section 14, Institutional and Human Resource Development - the DA will also a part on the development of Human Resource for farmers and fisherfolks such as Capacity Building, Skills training, scholarship program and the likes.  5. Section 15, Research, Development and Extension (RDE) -  The DA also assigned on the development on formulation and implementation of the Researches and Extension program.

title: High Value Crops Development Program
description:
High Value Crops Development Program (HVCDP) is in line with the Republic Act 7900 (High Value Crops Development Act of 1995). This is an act to promote the production, processing, marketing and distribution of high value crops. HVCDP is a priority program of the Department of Agriculture created to help address food security, poverty alleviation and sustainable growth through increased farm income and productivity. The target service areas include convergence areas, strategic production zones and farm households. These areas need the interventions from the government in terms of production, extension, processing, marketing and regulatory support. The program is implemented yearly with a coverage of implementation down to barangay levels. The budgetary allocation for the implementation of PAP for the HVCDP is taken from the GAA with a cost sharing arrangement scheme. A specific guidelines in the PAPs implementation is being followed  by the DA RFUs together with partner implementers.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              
Components of the Program include:
 i. Production Support Services (PSS);
 ii. Market Development Services (MDS);
 iii. Extension Support, Education and Training Support Services (ESETS);
 iv. Research and Development (R&D) for the National High Value Crops Program;
 v. Irrigation Network Planning and Contract Management Services  for the National High Value Crops Program; and
 vi. Provision of Agricultural Equipment and Facilities (PAEF)  for the National High Value Crops Program.
The objectives of the project/programs are as follow:
- Delivery of appropriate development support services
- Facilitate and harmonize development interventions in the strategic production areas/zones
- Facilitate and promote access to local and international market
- Proactive management actions on demand and supply situation
The Thrusts and Priorities include:
- Advancement of efficiency level of farm operation and management
- Enhance productivity and production of priority commodities
- Advancement of efficiency level of farm operation and management
- Compliance with export protocol and product standards
- Support for the processing and value adding of high value crops  
- High value crops linked to local and international markets
- Steady supply and prices of priority commodities
- Promotion of food security in schools and communities by introducing the values of basic food production                                                                                                                                                                                
   Strategic Directions:
- Provide quality planting materials for priority commodities to enhance productivity and production
- Improve commodity competitiveness in order to reduce importation of various vegetables
- Employ value chain analysis approach as tool for value adding and product development
- Productivity enhancement through the conduct of technology demonstration on the proper management of old trees (rejuvenation and rehabilitation program)
- Establish production facilities and postharvest equipment and machineries
- Establish school gardens and household gardens as source of vegetables for consumption and marketing
- Support the full utilization of local and traditional crop species with net potential
- Research, development and extension services
- Coordinate and support to food safety and consumerâ€™s welfare
- Build stronger coordination and partnership with LGUs, POs and stakeholders

title: Mindanao Inclusive Agricultural Development Project (MIADP)
description:
The Mindanao Inclusive Agricultural Development Project (MIADP) covers six (6) Regions in Mindanao including Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM) for the period FY 2021-2027 with an estimated project cost of PhP 6.8 Billion. MIADP intends to provide various agri.-fishery interventions appropriate for the Indigenous Cultural Communities/Indigenous Peoples (ICCs/IPs) in Mindanao. These interventions are geared towards improving the income of farmers and fisherfolk tailored to the Indigenous Knowledge System and Practices (IKSPs) in Mindanao Regions through the implementation of sustainable rural development strategies relative to poverty reduction program of the Government.
Objective:
The project aims to increase income of farmers and fisherfolk in the ICCs/IPs through the  development of sustainable agri.-fishery-based economic activities.
1.	To organize and strengthen the ICCs/IPs through capability building in planning, implementing and monitoring the interventions provided by the project. 
2.	To increase agricultural production of ICCs/IPs.
3.	To increase volume of sales of targeted agri.-fishery commodities of participating ICCs/IPs.
4.	To improve accessibility to transport agriculture and fishery-based products to the market.

5.	To increase employment opportunities in the ICCs/IPs.
expected_outputs:
Number of organized community by Ethno linguistic groups, youth and women
Increased in volume of the produce of targeted products
Increased in volume of marketed outputs of targeted products
Generated employment to the communities

title: NDA - Comparative Impact Study of Dairy Farming vs. Pure Crop Farming as Poverty Reduction Strategy
description:
Dairy Farming has always been construed to be a prohibitive and labor-intensive farming activity unlike crop farming.  Government investments have always been hugely spent for rice and high value crops while dairy programs were minimally funded in comparison.  

Statistics show that despite the lack of investments, the growth of the dairy sector has been at an average of 6.3% (2010-2015).  Small hold dairy farmers have considered dairy farming as their livelihood that can provide for their families needs.  The most compelling reason why dairy farmers continue to pursue dairying as a living is profit.

The government, the private sector and future dairy players need to be convinced that dairy farming and all of its related activities are profitable, hence, need investments.  The local dairy industry needs to be promoted as one of the agricultural commodity poverty reduction driver particularly in the rural areas.  Studies shall be documented and backed up by scientific evidence to firm up the cause, hence, this study.
expected_outputs:
1. Scientific evidence on the benefits of dairy farming published
2. Dairy farming as a viable enterprise alongside other agricultural commodities promoted
3. Private and government sector investments on dairy programs encourage 
4. poverty reduction

title: NDA - Dairy Goat Farming: A Livelihood Opportunity for Rural Farm families
description:
The proposed program will revolve around a community dairy goat farming concept. In this concept, communities will be identified where dairy goat farms will be established and will function as a goat multiplier farm, dairy production area, and learning site. In this arrangement, farmers will raise the animals given to them by the program in a common area with complete facilities and provision of necessary implements. They will be assisted too in the marketing through the program initiatives.

The implementation of the program will be by module, wherein one beneficiary community will receive one. A module of this program will have the following components: 100 breeder does and 5 breeder bucks; 1 goat house; Developed pasture; Milking and milk processing and storage equipment; Farm implements; Barn and storage; Starting feeds, drugs, and biologics; and Training of recipients.

The beneficiaries shall provide an agricultural land area (minimum of 4 hectares) for the project as a counterpart. The daily operations and accompanying costs of operation will be shouldered by the beneficiaries. The farmer beneficiaries and their families will operate the farm, each owning 10 heads of does. The milk produced will be processed in the farm and will be marketed as a whole. Income will then be divided among the beneficiaries depending on the volume of their production on a day-to-day basis.

In the aspect of marketing, the program had included the milk-feeding strategy to ensure a ready market for the milk produced by the farms. The milk-feeding concept will be an outfit that will buy the milks produced and processed by the modules and bring it for milk-feeding programs for malnourished children in the locality. With this set-up, the program will not only resolve the market obstacle, but will help address malnutrition among children.

This is designed to safeguard the project and the animals from threats like non-compliance of beneficiaries, lack of resources, and poor monitoring and to ensure that the targets are achieved and the recipients will experience the impact of the program in their lives.
expected_outputs:
As envisioned, this program shall impact the local dairy industry and the lives of the direct and indirect beneficiaries. The following are the projected effects of the program after 3 years:

1.        Directly benefit 750 family recipients by providing livelihood and training
2.        Increase the dairy goat population up to 20% 
3.        Increase the local goatsâ€™ milk production by 2.75 million L 
4.        Increase the local milk supply by 1%
5.        Generate Php 275 Million revenue to farmers 
6.        Improve the genetics of local dairy goat herd
7.        Benefit a total of 2,250 children who are raised from malnutrition

title: NDA - Dairy Industry Development Program (formerly Dairy Enterprise Development Program)
description:
The Dairy Industry Development Program aims to accelerate the development and growth of the Philippine dairy industry through policy direction, program coordination and implementation towards the enhanced growth and competitiveness of the industry with the end in view of achieving adequate supply of safe, quality milk and milk products  contributing  to food security, to provide livelihood opportunities and thereby increase incomes of small rural-based dairy farmers and proper nutrition for local consumers.

As the sole government agency that serves as the central policy determining and directing body mandated thru the National Dairy Development Act (RA7884) to carry out the Dairy Industry Development Program, the National Dairy Authority (NDA) possesses the power to formulate and execute dairy programs that will see the achievement of the purpose of the law.

The NDA has created programs and projects that will increase the base population of dairy animals to increase milk volumes, empower dairy farmers and other stakeholders, facilitate the provision of dairy facilities and equipment, provide access to market and promote the marketability of locally produced milk.  

The main programs that NDA pursues implementation include: 
  - Dairy Herd Build- Up Program;
  - Dairy Enterprise Development Program
  - Milk Feeding Program; and 
  - Dairy Regulatory Program

3. Number of children served in milk feeding activities
4. Number of Milk laboratories established/enhanced.

title: NDA - Empowering Communities through Enhancing Extension Services and Dairy-based Livelihood
description:
A. Infrastructure

1. Establishment of Dairy Marketing Centers 
a. These marketing centers, equipped with chillers, shall be established within existing NDA-assisted dairy zones or dairy areas. It must be situated in strategic areas or commercial centers where local consumers can easily access the products. 
b. Dairy farmers can go to these dairy marketing centers to sell their products. Since smallhold dairy farmers will undergo capability training on home based processing, they will be able to process their own products, sell through these marketing centers and earn more income.  
c.  The NDA will initially oversee the center under its Business Development Unit and eventually tap the NDA trained personnel of the Federation or dairy cooperatives to manage or run the centers. The dairy cooperatives/federations/private entities shall pay corresponding commissioned-based fees to NDA for every product sold in the center. The fees collected will go back to the marketing centers to cover the maintenance costs.
d. NDA will continuously monitor the marketing centers.

2. Establishment of Dairy Post-harvest facilities 
a. Post-harvest facilities such as milk collection centers with cold storage equipment shall be established to ensure the quality of milk collected for processing plants. 
b. Farmers can go to these collection centers and sell their raw milk produce and the collection center will bring the milk to the milk processing plant.
c. The NDA will establish these milk collection centers and shall be leased (Lease to own scheme) to cooperatives or federations.
d. Through a partnership forged between the federation or cooperatives and the marketing center thru NDA, products from the milk processing plants will be supplied to the marketing centers.

B. Capacity Building

As the country recognizes the need to develop its dairy industry, priority programs such as training programs for dairy farmers and cooperatives shall be enhanced. Dairy sector’s competiveness and capacities will be fully strengthened in the country as extension services will continue to magnify its horizons by providing adequate and timely training and education. The following trainings will be conducted:
a. Homebased Milk Processing
b. Milk Quality Assurance
c. Business Management (Accounting & Bookkeeping)
d. Milk Marketing
e. Trainings on other business opportunities (meat processing (for male calves), vermi-culture, biogas, forage production)

This project aims to enhance existing dairy-based livelihood particularly on milk collection, processing and marketing to make dairying a sustainable source of income for dairy farmers. It intends to promote the marketability of locally produced milk and milk products.
expected_outputs:
1. Some 4,000 dairy farmers all over the country will be trained
2. Seven (7) dairy marketing centers will be established in selected areas
3. Seven (7) milk collection centers will be established in selected areas

title: NDA - Farm Mechanization
description:
Dairy farming today requires the use of farm machineries and equipment which are considered valuable inputs particularly in forage production and pasture development.  While such equipment offers a wide range of benefits in terms of developing and increasing production of forage for dairy animals, not all dairy farmers have the capacity to purchase their own equipment taking into account the financial obligations that they need to fulfil in managing their respective farms.

As the agency mandated to accelerate the development of the local dairy industry, the NDA is committed to providing the local dairy farmers the access to various dairy equipment and facilities that can be of great help in improving their dairy farm operations. It is in this light, that the NDA would like to propose the provision of one (1) agricultural tractor, one (1) forage chopper, one (1) truck, and one (1) warehouse to each of the six (6) Regional Departments of the NDA namely, Northern Luzon, Southern Luzon, Central Visayas, Western Visayas, Northern Mindanao and Southern Mindanao. 

The NDA shall be the executing agency of the project whose major tasks include: formulating rules and guidelines as regards to the use of the tractor and forage chopper; deployment of the equipment to the requesting farmers/farmers' groups; overall maintenance of the equipment; and conduct of regular monitoring of the project. 

The NDA uses this proposed project as the vehicle to support local dairy farmers in their goal of further enhancing dairy farm operations to achieve better milk yield and ensuring the availability of feeds for dairy animals. In addition, the agency seeks to develop more contract growers to serve as feeds source of the local dairy farmers and contract growers for specialized skills in calf rearing and grow-out farming. 

The tractors, trucks, and forage choppers would be provided on hire basis to the local dairy farmers through the NDA Regional Department assisting them. Each department shall be responsible in ensuring the equity in the distribution of assistance to the farmers.

The project will enhance farm operations and increase forage production of local dairy farmers. It also aims to develop more contract growers as feeds source.
expected_outputs: Dairy machineries will be leased dairy farmers. This is an income generating project of the NDA

title: NDA - Partnership Arrangement for the Establishment and Operation of a Dairy Cattle Production and Rearing Farm Business for Dairy Development
description:
The NDA and the partner shall enter into a Partnership Agreement for the Establishment and Operation of a Dairy Cattle Production and Rearing Farm Business for Dairy Development with the following features:

1. Dairy cattle production, upgrading, and rearing shall be undertaken in the farm.  
 
2. The NDA shall provide dairy heifers/cows as its equity in the partnership including support systems for breeding such as dairy semen, breeding paraphernalia, liquid nitrogen, semen tank, and the like.

3. The partner shall provide the suitable farm for the equivalent number of cattle with grazing areas, feeds and forage, corresponding cattle sheds and milking parlor, and other farm infrastructure and utilities like electricity and water.  

4. The sharing of profits/losses shall be proportionate to the respective project equity.

5. Joint project management shall be exercised by both parties through equal representation in the Project Management Group. Daily farm management shall be the partner's responsibility.


The project aims to: 1) increase the number and quality of local dairy animals through the establishment and operation of dairy cattle production and rearing farm; and 2) improve dairy cattle production systems through the creation of local sources of dairy cattle in partnership with the private sector.
expected_outputs:
1. Established a dairy cattle production and rearing farm that will supply dairy cattle as required by farmers in existing and new dairy areas.
2. The project will produce 1,901 heads of diry cattle out of the 200 foundation stocks provided
3. A total of 13.03 million liters will be produced by the dairy cows raised in the dairy farm.
4. The dairy farm is expected to earn income from sale of milk and dairy cows.

title: NDA - Rural Dairy Industry Development
description:

Also, more stock farms will be established to accommodate more dairy animals. Latest technology in animal breeding and milk collection will be made available in these farms/centers. 

The project moves along the programs of rural industrialization and industry dispersal as provided for in Republic Act 8435, also known as the Agriculture and Fisheries Modernization Act (AFMA). The establishment of milk processing centers and engagement in dairy farming will give opportunities for employment to residents in rural areas near the centers and farms and will reduce propensity to migrate to urban areas.

The project aims to contribute in the dairy industry development in the country, specifically:

  - To create livelihood and employment opportunities in accordance to the rural industrialization and dispersal programs provided for in the AFMA.

title: NDA - Strengthening Capacities of Dairy Farmers & Extension Workers
description:
The National Dairy Authority (NDA) was established in 1995. It is the central policy determining and directing body tasked to ensure the accelerated development of the Philippine dairy industry through policy direction and program coordination and implementation. The main goal of the NDA is to establish a profitable, competitive and sustainable growing dairy industry built on financially viable business performance throughout the value chain, providing good quality of life for farmers and ensuring consumers safe and quality milk and milk products.Majority of the Philippines’s annual dairy requirement is supplied by importers and processors. Local production continues to increase annually but not enough to cover local demand. In 2017 it imported 417,07 million kilograms of milk by 185 importers, processors and traders. In same year local production was only 22,76 million kilograms of milk. Milk is third largest agri-import.Philippines’s dairy sector represents a big potential for an improvement of a quality of life in rural areas. Development of milk production will have positive effects on unemployment rate and socio-economic situation in rural areas.  The NDA is given very limited funds every year to capacitate a total of 2,418 dairy farmers in dairy production and management. The lack of funds contributed to the very limited technical assistance the NDA can provide to these dairy farmers resulting to wrong practices and not enough knowledge to run a dairy enterprise and make it profitable.

The NDA is focused on improvement of situation. In 2017, the NDA and Czech Republic’s Development Assistance (program Aid for Trade of the Ministry of Industry and Trade of the Czech Republic) have started a new project focused on situation of dairy sector in Philippines - “Assistance in analyzing and improving value chains in the dairy industry in Philippines”. In scope of the project, Czech dairy experts have visited Philippines’s farms. They have identified three main issues that are complicating development of dairy industry in Philippines:
insufficient capacities of extension workers
- insufficient capacities of dairy farmers 
- insufficient promotion of local (Philippines’s) production and consumption

The proposed project is consistent with and directly supports the NDA Charter Statement and Strategy Map (Annex A) of improving the stakeholders’ welfare, ensuring the enforcement of dairy quality standards from production to post-harvest, advocate for the patronage of local milk and milk products and enhancing the competency of NDA manpower and farmer-clients.
Finally, the proposed project will help realize the Philippine Agriculture’s goals of expanding opportunities for those engaged in agriculture production and increasing access of small and subsistence farmers to economic opportunities as stipulated in Chapter 8 of the Philippine Development Plan (PDP) 2017-2022.
expected_outputs:
The project “Strengthening Capacities of Dairy Farmers & Extension Workers” has three main outputs.

OUTPUT 1: Capacity of dairy extension workers have been increased
First output will be achieved by training of 20 dairy extensions workers of NDA in 4 Philippines’s regions. It will be also achieved by creation of guidebook for dairy workers on animal welfare, animal nutrition, breeding, and dairy product processing. 

OUTPUT 2: Capacity of dairy farmers have been increased
Second output will be achieved by training of 80 to 200 dairy farmers in 4 Philippines’s regions. It will be also achieved by creation of guidebook for dairy workers on animal welfare, animal nutrition, breeding, and dairy product processing. 

OUTPUT 3: Philippines local milk consumption have been promoted
Third output will be achieved by creation of a website for promotion of consumption of local milk products.

title: PCC - National Dairy Herd Improvement Program (NDHIP) and Enterprise Build Up
description:
The Dairy Herd Improvement Program (DHIP) is sometimes referred to as DHI, DHIA, or DHIR specifically for large animals. This valuable tool helps evaluate the progress of the herd’s milk production while addressing the improvement of the different production management system including breeding, health and nutrition. Through the DHIP, the breeding program of the carabaos at the local level will have a clear direction and its progress is measured over time to ensure that the animals are improving in terms of breeding performance. The DHIP is fairly inexpensive, useful and exciting activity that only requires constant monitoring and evaluation including documentation of activities.

In addition, the dairy herd improvement (DHI) system has a played a critical role in the advancement of the dairy industry.  Even today, it remains an important link in the industry. However, dairy industry changes, such as animal number decreases and shifts, dairy management advances, and on-farm economics, pose significant challenges to DHI. The nature of the dairy market, changing technology, and competitive pressures indicate the need for strategic planning and implementation among DHI participants, players and stakeholders.

The project is expected to benefit some 150,000 dairy farmers and 190 organized groups.

title: PhilFIDA - Abaca Tuxy Buying Special Project (ATBSP)
description:
The Abaca Tuxy Buying Special Project (ATBSP) is the new approach to be implemented by the Philippine Fiber Industry Development Authority (PhilFIDA) in the production of excellent abaca fiber. This scheme will ensure the survival of abaca which is indigenous to the Philippines. Using a corporative approach, the project aims to organize and empower most of the abaca farmers nationwide as a cooperative, produce their own abaca fibers as a group which will redound to better competitive price, quality and quantity and sell their harvest directly to Grading and Baling Establishments (GBEs) and local processors. A group of abaca farmers with contiguous abaca farms for at least one hectare per farmer shall be formed into a cooperative with at least 100 active farmer-members and should be accredited with the Department of Agriculture (DA).  This project also aims to reduce the activity being done by the farmers to increase their productivity. The traditional way of abaca fiber extraction/harvesting by the abaca farmers has twelve (12) stages.  The project intends to lessen it to only six (6) steps --Topping, Tumbling, Tuxying, Tuxy Bundling, Tuxy Transporting/Hauling and Tuxy Trading /Selling --  thereby removing and easing the burden of the abaca farmers of the other six (6) activities and just let them continue producing all the abaca tuxies they want for the day before selling it to their cooperative that same day. This will surely increase abaca fiber production.

The project has an estimated budgetary requirement of about P20 million to cover the warehouse, stripping, drying and office buildings, equipment and facilities, hauling truck and motorcycles and seed capital for the initial operation. Feasibility study and logical framework was conducted and formulated thus, ready for takeoff once budget is available.

ATBSP is aligned to the newly approved Abaca Industry Roadmap of PhilFIDA. It is expected to meet the demand for the high-quality abaca fibers and uplift the status of life of abaca farmers most specially the indigenous people in rural areas.
expected_outputs: The project aims to increase income of abaca farmers who are members of an abaca farmer cooperative under the Abaca Tuxy Buying Special Project by at least 100%.
pdp_indicators: Economic opportunities in agriculture, forestry and fisheries expanded
pdp_ss_outcomes: Agriculture, forestry and fishery-based enterprises increased

title: PhilFIDA - Catanduanes Abaca Productivity Enhancement Project (CAPE)
description:
The Project aims to enhance abaca farm productivity and sustain an annual production rate increase of 2% through provision of production support for the rehabilitation and development of abaca farms in the province.

1. Treat a total of 1,100 hectares  of abaca areas with an average disease incidence of 10%       
2. Replant a total of 3,000 hectares of abaca plantations that are typhoon damaged, planted with traditional low yielding varieties and with sufficient shade trees, involving 3000 abaca farmers/landowners                                                                                                               
3. Develop a total of 400 hectares of new abaca plantations (expansion) involving 800 abaca farmers/landowners
4. Establish a total of 11 semi-high density abaca nursery in the 11 municipalities of the province(one hectare per municipality
5. Provide postharvest devices for the production of standard grades of abaca fiber.

1,100 hectares of abaca areas treated
3,000 hectares of abaca plantations replanted
400 hectares of new abaca plantations involving 800 abaca farmers/ landowners
11 semi high density abaca nursery in the 11 municipalities

title: PhilFIDA - Cotton Development Project
description:
The demand for tropical fibers in the production of locally-made fabrics for use in government offices and functions per R.A. 9242, s. 2004, and the need to supply the requirement for raw materials of local weavers and knitters make the support to the Philippine fiber industry imperative.    

Cotton, as a primary component of home-made fabrics, having been grown for long in the country as an industry, is among the major fibers that need to be revitalized and sustained. The Philippines used to produce cotton supplying a portion of the need of the textile mills in the country. Highest production was attained in 1992 when area planted to cotton reached 35,000 hectares and produced 14,400 MT raw cotton fiber (cotton lint). However, due to serious economic and technical considerations on cotton growing in recent years, there had been a substantial decline in hectarage and participation in the industry, with areas just primarily confined in research stations to date. 

 In as much as a home-grown cotton production technology had been developed, along with the availability of physical resources that convert cotton harvests into raw fiber, waiting to be refurbished for immediate use, cotton cultivation and processing can be sustained with proper support from the government. 

To revitalize the cotton industry in order to sustain the production of cotton fibers for small-scale cotton users, such as local loom-weavers and knitters, and eventually for commercial-size cotton production and utilization.
expected_outputs: To initiate the establishment of cotton production bases in Luzon, Visayas and Mindanao as sources of locally-produced cotton fibers for loom-weavers and knitters, providing the needed production and processing support, training and technical assistance, for timely input and service delivery, and higher farm productivity;

pdp_ss_outcomes: Agriculture, forestry and fisheries productivity within ecological limit improved / Agriculture, forestry and fishery-based enterprises increased / Access to value chains increased

description:
The Project aim is to uplift the livelihood and social status of the abaca farmers. To organize an abaca farmers cooperative in which they will be able to enjoy its benefits and gains out of their own abaca products.

Purpose of the project are the ff:


1. Establish cooperative-operated abaca nurseries adopting the rapid eyebud propagation technique for the production and distribution of abaca planting materials                                     
2. Establish a facility for use by the cooperatives as fiber stripping/processing/ storage               
3. Provide abaca stripping machines  to the cooperatives for use in stripping of tuxies bought from its members
4. Train members of the cooperatives particularly women,youth differently-abled persons and senior citizens on semi-processing of abaca
5. Conduct training of members of cooperatives as social preparation                                        
6. Train coop officers and operations managers on the management of the abaca tuxy buying

description:
Through the provision of processing/weaving centers with complete facilities, tools and devices to the cooperatives, an increased supply of handwoven fabrics made of abaca and other indigenous materials is expected which will uplift the living conditions of the members of the communities. The effect will benefit not only the members of the cooperatives but also their immediate families. A progressive weaving community with entrepreneurial capability is also expected with an expanded local and international market for fiber and fiber-based products. The LGUs in which the weaving communities are situated would benefit by promoting these establishments as a “one-stop-shop” for tourist and visitors.

It can be accomplished by provision of infrastructures/facilities needed by the weaving communities, training them to improve their capability in order to avail of the income-generating opportunities as entrepreneurs.

title: PhilFIDA - PhilFIDA ICT Project
description:
Technical assistance and advisory services, information, education and communication support services for farmers’ groups and agricultural technicians of the Local Government Units (LGUs) and training services are among those banner programs of PhilFIDA. Information needed in the implementation of these programs is dispersed to all provincial and regional offices. Obtaining such information from one office to another may cause some difficulty and a possible duplication of efforts in maintaining similar systems and/or databases across different field offices occurs due to the geographical concerns. Obviously, there is a need to integrate information sources and build-up an agency-wide knowledge databank and up-to-date web portal to ensure easy access to updated, relevant and timely information. Improvement of electronic links within the organization as well as with the other external entities is also necessary. 

Data and information systems on the geographical location of programs and projects of the agency presented in electronic maps are also needed to be developed for effective monitoring and to reduce the need for clients to physically go to PhilFIDA offices to avail of services or obtain the information they need. An improved internal system can be better delivered through the use of latest technologies on intranet and extranet solutions, particularly through web-enabled applications.

Voice and data communication technologies can manage coordinative works between central office and different provincial and regional offices. Centralized system within the agency will further enhance productivity through web-enabled applications.

The ISSP aims to guide PhilFIDA in the implementation of its ICT initiatives and projects to enhance its performance and achieve its goals. This also includes the proposed ICT organizational structure to cope with changing requirements and fast-paced technology.

This ISSP covers the Central Office, Laboratories, Experimental Stations and all Regional and Provincial Offices of PhilFIDA.
expected_outputs: The project aims to modernized the processes of the agency in the performance of its functions. Support to operation by providing ICT equipment, device and paraphernalia to fast track the performance of the activities.
pdp_indicators: Economic opportunities in agriculture, forestry and fisheries expanded

title: PhilFIDA - Provision of Agricultural Equipment and Facilities (PAEF) ( formerly Provision of Fiber Extraction Facility for Abaca Fiber Production)
description:
To enhanced fiber productivity, the Philippine Fiber Industry Development Authority (PhilFIDA) thru Fiber Utilization and Technology Division (FUTD) will provide support services to  farmers, housewife in the different provinces of the country by providing additional agricultural facilities such as Mobile Spindle Stripping Machine (MSSM), Stripping and Drying Shed, MultiFiber Decorticating Machine (MFDM) with safety mechanism, Improved Handstripping Device (IHSD), Stripping Knives, construction of Abaca processing center and warehousing for the production of abaca, pineapple, banana and other plant fibers to further increase productivity and sustainable supply of good quality  fibers for fabric manufacture, pulp, cordage and handicraft. The facilities to be provided are intended to be used by a cluster of organized group of farmers cultivating a total of 50 hectares per cluster.  The facilities will be provided/distributed to the farmer beneficiaries through cooperatives in coordination with the Local Government Units (LGU) of municipalities/ provinces considering  abaca, pineapple and banana and other plant fiber as a priority crop.  Initiatives from the private sector are also encouraged to contribute in the development of  these fibercrop.  The distribution scheme is contained in a Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) between PhilFIDA in concerned regions/provinces and local government units. Prior to selection of intended beneficiaries, criteria for section has to be considered.  The commercial uses of abaca and other fibers includes its importance as a raw material in the manufacture of textile, pulp and specialty paper, cordage and other fiber-based products. 

To increase fiber production  that will increase productivity of fiber producers and thereby increasing fiber supply needed by the market
expected_outputs: Improvement of fiber quality through Improved Hand Stripping Device, Spindle Stripping Machine, Multi-Fiber Decorticating Machine and  Sustainable Agricultural Development
pdp_indicators: Economic opportunities in agriculture, forestry and fisheries expanded
pdp_ss_outcomes: Agriculture, forestry and fisheries productivity within ecological limit improved / Agriculture, forestry and fishery-based enterprises increased

title: PhilFIDA - Research and Development Program for Fiber Processing and Utilization
description:
The PhilFIDA -FUTD undertakes R & D activities on fiber processing and utilization to address issues and concerns related to fiber production, quality and utilization of natural fibers such as abaca, banana, pineapple, sisal and other minor fibers. Specifically, the sub-program component undertakes the following;1.1 Design/development/improvement of  machines/tools/devices;  1.2.  Identification of new uses for natural fibers to promote their utilization development and identification of new uses for natural fibers to promote their utilization in line with environment  conciousness for green economy and utilization of renewable resources; 1.3  Raw material manipulation of fibers to create a variety of different effects using fibers, fabrics and other materials for the different fiber properties 1.4 Disseminate developed  technologies as technology source for community -based livelihood project in coordination with ESETS. The Fiber Utilization and Technology Division (FUTD) personnel who developed the technologies acted as Resource Speaker in disseminating  the techniques, cost and return analysis and sustainability approaches for each recipient association/organization/cooperative to develop them into a   business enterprise as source of livelihood.
1.4  Laboratory services on fiber identification, analysis of morphological, physical and chemical properties of fibers are undertaken to cater to the needs of the industry stakeholders such as the farmers, cordage makers, pulp processors and trade exporters of raw fibers. The Fiber Processing and Utilization Laboratory (FPUL) provides state-of-the-art capabilities for the testing and study of natural fibers emphasizing the characteristics to achieve desired fiber properties and functions.  It is a science-based user facility simultaneously developing strong scientific programs while offering broad access to its capabilities and collaboration. The FPUL can assist the businesses in complying with the requests needed.  The sectors that would most likely support the upgrading of the FPUL are the farmers, fiber processors, academe, private businessmen and LGUs. In all cases, the local government units always request FPUL for technical assistance in terms of value-adding activities and income generation/employment opportunities.  These activities can easily be adapted by their constituents because of the following reasons: a.  Doable and can be considered as a backyard industry b.  Developed products 

1. Developed machines/tools /devices ; 2. Generated technologies on fiber proccessing and utilization that can be disseminated to industry sector and communities in coordination with LGUs to improve livelihood
expected_outputs: 1. Researches on the improvement and development of machines, tools and devices for plant fibers and for the production of fiber-based products, production and improve the fiber quality for global competitiveness; 2. Development and identification of new uses for natural fibers to promote their utilization in line with environment  consciousness for green economy and utilization of renewable resources;  3. Transfer of technology on fiber extraction using the PhilFIDA-designed Improved Hand Stripping Device (IHSD), Mobile Spindle Stripping Machine (MSSM), Multi-Fiber  Decorticating Machine (MFDM)  with safety mechanism, Three-Series  Spindle Stripping Machine, Tandem Multi-Fiber Decorticating Machine with safety mechanism and the developed technology on fiber utilization.
pdp_indicators: Access to economic opportunities by small farmers and fisherfolk increased / Economic opportunities in agriculture, forestry and fisheries expanded
pdp_ss_outcomes: Access to technology increased
regions: NCR - National Capital Region

title: PhilFIDA-Development of Sustainable Abaca Industry in Eastern Visayas
description:
Eastern Visayas is among the top abaca producing region in the Philippines. According to the Bureau of Agricultural Statistics (BAS), abaca production in the regions amounted to 20,000 metric tons in 2011, making it the second highest producer of abaca in the country following the Bicol region. It also had 39,500 hectares of land planted to abaca in that year1. With the continued introduction of new applications and other significant uses, abaca strengthen its position as one of the major crops in the country with high export potential and continues to be one of the main sources of income among farmers in the region. 

Through the years, the productions of abaca were drastically going down because of the infestation of abaca diseases and natural calamities that hits the region. Several abaca areas are now unproductive because of slow rehabilitation activities due to lack of fund for this purpose. 

This proposal aims to rejuvenate the abaca industry in the region by rehabilitating abaca areas specially those already been treated under the abaca disease management project, to open new abaca areas, establishment of nurseries, distribution of farm inputs and capability building.

Increase farmers' income through increase in production
expected_outputs: Six (6) hectares open-type abaca nursery;  Five- hundred (500) hectares new abaca areas developed; Six hundred fifty (650) hectares abaca area rehabilitated;  One thousand six hundred (1600)  hectares abaca areas treated; three (3) units spindle stripping machine procured, Six (6)  units fiber stripping shed established;  two (2) training of trainers on Abaca Production Technologies Conducted, One (1) training of trainers on Fiber-Based Livelihood Projects and three (3) Information Drive on Abaca Fiber Production Conducted; and  Tissue Culture and Diagnostic  Laboratories Operationalized

title: PhilFIDA-Enhancing Agricultural Competence and Productivities of the Indigenous Peoples of North Cotabato
description:
Indigenous People (IP) of North Cotabato remains to be  among the poorest of the poor despite the rich, abundant, & vast tract of ancestral domain lands. North Cotabato province registered a high poverty incidence of 34.5% in 2015. One of the suitable crops under these lush forestal areas is abaca which is traditioanally cultivated  by these IP's as part of their culture and a major source of their income. However, financial constraints of these IP's to purchase farm inputs and machineries hinders them to exploit the high demand and  prices of excellent quality abaca fiber which resulted to low productivity. 

To improve the socio-economic condition of Indigenous People in North Cotabato by harnessing the potential of their ancestral lands and maximizing abaca productivity.

Developed 4,500 hectares of new abaca areas
Established 9 units pre-germination nursery areas
Provided 72 units abaca stripping machines and 2 units hauling truck

title: Philippine Rural Development Project
description:
PRDP is a six-year national government platform for a modern and climate-smart agriculture to be pursued through partnerships with local government units and agri-fishery stakeholders. It will take-off from the gains and lessons of various DA programs such as project tracking by geo-tagging and building capacity of LGUs and farming and fishing communities to manage and sustain agri-fishery support infrastructure and services, among others.
The Project will operationalize the national and regional Agriculture and Fishery Modernization Plans (AFMPs) through integration of plans at the provincial level. Also, the Project will be guided by the vulnerability and suitability assessment framework, which was initially used for the Central Philippines Rural Development Project (CPRDP) preparation. Also, it will develop value chain roadmaps that will serve as an input in the selection and prioritization of investments in the target areas.

The Project is aligned with the goals and priorities of the Philippine Development Plans (2011-2016) for a competitive and sustainable agriculture and fisheries sectors, will provide program-level support for the Agriculture and Fisheries Modernization Act of 1997 (RA 8435) and advances the principles of Agrikulturang Pinoy (AgriPinoy) of sustainable resource management, local development and full service delivery from farm to table.

Local Planning: this component aims to enhance the Agricultural and Fisheries Modernization Plan through science-based tools and to harmonize regional and provincial Agriculture and Fisheries Modernization Plan through the formulation of the Provincial Commodity Investment Plan using value chain approach.

Infrastructure Development: this component aims to improve the links from production areas to markets to enhance the efficiency of transporting agricultural products. It also aims for higher productivity as a result of increased cropping intensity and yields, food security and improved health from readily available potable water and lower post harvest losses resulting in higher volume of outputs and more efficient support facilities.

Enterprise Development: this component aims to engage broad sections of the sector in the production of marketable surplus through investments in strategic segments of priority commodity value chains and strengthening collaboration between DA and the Local Government Units. It shall strengthen and develop viable agri-fishery based enterprises through efficient value chain of key regional agri-fishery product.

Project Support: this component aims to provide efficient and effective project management and implementation, establish a standard on services and technical assistance and effective mode of engagement with LGUs.
expected_outputs:
(a) 16 regions with sub-projects under implementation
(b) 81 provinces with PCIPs prepared
(c) 3,600 km of roads and 2,000 linear meters of bridges  constructed/rehabilitated 
(d) 550 hectares of irrigation services areas generated from newly constructed rehabilitated CIS
(e) 45,000 households provided with access to rehabilitated/constructed PWS
(f) 300 units of various post production and marketing facilities constructed/rehabilitated
(g)  1,500 enterprise established along the priority value chain

(Above listed items are outputs of the original loan and expansion of PRDP)
pdp_indicators: Access to economic opportunities by small farmers and fisherfolk increased / Economic opportunities in agriculture, forestry and fisheries expanded
pdp_ss_outcomes: Agriculture, forestry and fishery-based enterprises increased / Access to value chains increased / Agriculture, forestry and fisheries productivity within ecological limit improved / Access to technology increased

title: PHilMech - Postproduction Loss Assessment of Selected Fruits and Vegetables
description:
Due to its highly perishable characteristics, postharvest losses from fruits and vegetables are one of the highest source of losses incurred among agricultural crops. Postproduction loss assessment of selected fruits and vegetables was done in late 2009. Thus, measurement of abovementioned losses has to be updated and estimate new figures for other crops that will serve as baseline.   

As a commitment to the PDP 2017-2022 per agreement during the Mid-term Updating, PHilMech is expected to update and determine the magnitude of postharvest losses of selected fruits and vegetables on a regular basis which starts 2020 onwards.
expected_outputs: updated/established postharvest losses for selected fruits and vegetables

title: PRRI - Decision Support System for Rubber Production Using Geographical Information System (GIS) and Remote Sensing Technology
description:
The development of sustainable and improved production of rubber industry is anchored on proper and well-developed decision making, enhanced productivity to adopt new technology and innovation. An inclusive and globally competitive rubber industry providing sustainable benefits to all stakeholders is envisioned for the Philippine rubber industry, with the goal of increasing the benefits of all the stakeholders, thereby spreading the gains down to the smallholders in the remote barangays in all rubber producing provinces in the regions. For the past year, low production of rubber yield emerges as a major constraint in the rubber industry which is mainly attributed in low pricing, in addition the improper fertilization management/nutrient management, emergence of pests and diseases, uses of unsuited rubber clones for plantation, lack of information on rubber clone agronomic characteristics and natural calamities. The development of technologies to support decision-making in production, pricing, good agricultural practices, market, pest and diseases management. The derived information will be useful for the farmers, planners, and researchers. Philippines Rubber Research Institute (PRRI) needs timely accurate statistics on natural rubber regularly to monitor and to take suitable measures in the interest of the Philippines rubber sector.	

Generally, this study will enable the Philippine Rubber Research Institute (PRRI) to map the areas vulnerable to soil erosion, estimating the area for further cultivation, and clone suitability map through GIS and Remote Sensing technologies. Furthermore this study will assess the spatial distribution of rubber area over different classes of elevation and slope and the traditional rubber clone’s farmer’s preference, it will help to fully understand the dynamics of rubber plantation activity in the rubber traditional regions of the Philippines and understanding the variation in the productivity of rubber ecosystem in the Philippines.
expected_outputs:
1. Generate decision support tools.
 2. Generate data on the location of rubber.
 3. Create suitable measures in the interest of Rubber sector.
 4. Expansion of production and improvement of plantation/farm productivity by adopting recommended technology and good agricultural practices.

pdp_ss_outcomes: Access to technology increased

title: PRRI - Establishment of Budwood Garden in Rubber Farmers Cooperatives and Association
description:
Among the primary reasons for the slow expansion of rubber plantation in the country were lack of supply of quality planting materials, and low price of rubber products. One of the function of Philippine Rubber Research Institute (PRRI)  is to propagate and promote quality rubber planting materials, enable rubber industry stakeholders particularly smallholder rubber farmers to have access to quality rubber trees seedlings and showcase modern production techniques and other support services. With this project, it aims to comprehensively realize the goals of human empowerment and economic development in the countryside through programs and projects that will increase rubber production in the country and improve the quality of life especially in poor rural communities that depend primarily in this industry and to increase the available quality planting materials that are needed in the expansion of rubber areas.	

Specifically, the project aims to: 

(1) To increase production of rubber through distribution of quality planting materials that are needed for the expansion of rubber areas; and
(2) To establish and maintain PRRI Rubber Nursery in support to the distribution of quality planting materials to rubber farmer associations and cooperatives.

title: PRRI - Establishment of PRRI Laboratories and Shared Facilities
description:
The PRRI is mandated to consolidate, coordinate and strengthen the national rubber research and development program, while serving as the nerve center for plantation expansion and training activities for rubber producers, processors, and rubber product manufacturers. RA 10089 provides that the PRRI’s integral role in providing an enabling mechanism for technology development and incubation and eventually its diffusion into the natural rubber industry stakeholders in the upstream and downstream sectors.


With this, there is the immediate need to put up the shared facilities and laboratories. The shared facilities will consist of a dormitory, training center and museum while the laboratories will consist of soil, molecular, pest and disease diagnostic, rubber testing and tissue culture laboratory.

The project leads to strengthen the implementation of research and development activities, enhance the current rubber production for adaptation of rubber farmers, develop new technology to increase the rubber production in the country and enhanced  the development of technical expertise of rubber R&D/E workers.
expected_outputs:
(1) Established and operationalized shared facilities and laboratories
(2) 5 laboratories, 1 dormitory, 1 training center and 1 rubber museum will be established

title: PRRI - Expanded Capacity Development Program for Rubber Farmers Association and Cooperatives
description: With the recent technological advancements happening in the rubber industry, rubber stakeholders must be capacitated in order to address the need to increase production and be able to obtain a generous monthly income.  Production is not the sole problem that remains to be addressed, but also the low income of smallholders which is by far the rallying cry of every rubber farmer from now and then. Hence, this program aims to address this seemingly insurable crisis in the Philippine rubber economy.  Republic Act 10089 states, "undertake training and capacity-building programs for rubber producers, processors and cooperatives in order to increase production of quality rubber and raises level of income especially of poor smallholders." Given this function, PRRI shall conduct trainings/seminars/workshops to essentially capacitate the rubber smallholders, specifically the rubber farmers so that they will be alleviated from their former state of only earning meager income. Training to be conducted will enhance the knowledge and skills of rubber farmers in rubber plantation, and nursery and bud wood garden establishment and management, harvesting and post-harvesting of rubber to increase the productivity and improve the quality of rubber thus increase the income of rubber farmers.

(2) 15 trainings on Rubber Nursery and Budwood Garden Establishment

title: PRRI - Leaf Morpho-anatomy and Molecuclar Characterization Of Seven Recommended and 2000 series Hevea brasiliensis in the Philippines
description:
Seven recommended clones  (USM1, RRIM 600, PB 260, PB 330, PB 217, PB 235, PB 311) and 200 series rubber clones that are utilized for large scale planting possess unique characteristics which are adaptable in different agro-climatic conditions in diverse locations. However, some of the commercial rubber nurseries which are not accredited supply rubber seedlings that are not yet identified. This is due to the multiple combinations of different clones without proper recording such as lay-outing and tagging. Unidentified rubber clones gives a detrimental effect in clonal purity and in result, hampers the overall productivity of rubber.

This project aims to characterize the seven recommended and 200 series clones in the Philippines through morphological, anatomical, and molecular methods for proper clone identification of distributed rubber budded seedlings.

title: PRRI - Mapping Incidence and Distribution of Major Pests and  Diseases of Rubber in the Zamboanga Peninsula
description:
The rubber tree is subject to a plethora of economically important pathological problems, mainly of fungal origin, the Basidiomycetes. Pests and diseases of rubber could prevent and reduce the full yield potential in the rubber industry. 

Limited information can be found regarding the distribution of termite pest and fungal diseases of rubber in the Philippines. Knowledge on the spatial distribution of these diseases in and among rubber plantations and on consequences related to disease infection or disorder and eventual latex yield loss is important to consider in formulating effective integrated disease management strategies. This is also critical in sustaining the rubber industry especially in rehabilitating senile rubber plantations as planting materials can be severely infected to fungal diseases present in the field or from the neighboring rubber plantations. GIS maps are one of the tools in forecasting disease outbreaks and estimating damage and consequently in designing cost-effective and location-specific pest and disease management strategies appropriate for different cropping systems in the Zamboanga Peninsula. Thus, this study will potentially support the lack of technical knowledge of rubber farmers on rubber production and management especially on the control of pests and diseases in the region.
expected_outputs: One (1) production-related research and development activity conducted

title: PRRI - Nursery Selection and Seedling Evaluation Trial of Promising Ortet Clone Potential for Hevea Breeding in Zamboanga Sibugay
description:
Havea brasiliensis is a perennial out-breeder with a long lifespan which makes crop improvement laborious and time consuming. Breeding cycle in rubber extends to 20-30 years between pollination and yield assessment distributed over three selection stages. This justifies standardization of early selection methods to optimize and shorten the cycle as much as possible and one component of early selection is identification of traits at young age that have correlated response with yield at maturity and the other is combined management of different selection stages to improve the accuracy of estimation of genetic value.

This aims to determine the growth and yield performance of the ortet seedlings and discuss the observations on juvenile screening in Hevea breeding.
expected_outputs: One (1)new research production related and development activity conducted; Identified elite ortets in terms of growth and yield attributes that can be immediately adopted and potential for parental use for future breeding purposes;
